בפוסט הקודם (https://bit.ly/2GvIJhw) שיתפתי בהמלצות לתקשורת פנים ארגונית נכונה בתקופת הקורונה וכן שאלות שעובדים הציגו בפני הנהלת הארגון בגין חוסר הודאות ותחושות מצוקה. 

הפעם אשתף בסוגי מסרים שמומלץ לתקשר לעובדים בכדי להתמודד טוב יותר עם תחושותיהם:

1)    עדכון לגבי פעילות הארגון להגנה על עובדיו: אמצעי חיטוי, שימוש בחדרי ישיבות, חדר אוכל...

2)     עדכון שבועי מהמנכ"ל על השפעת הקורונה על התנהלות הארגון 

3)    עדכון לאחר כל שינוי נהלי משרד הבריאות המשפיעים  ישירות על הארגון 

4)    העבירו מסרים לדרגי ניהול שונים לגבי מדיניות הארגון ומה מצופה מהם.

5)    הנגישו לעובדים מידע חיוני כגון: הנחיות לבידוד, תסמינים להידבקות, טלפונים לשעת חירום ועוד.

6)    כנראה שגם אתם יצרתם נהלים חדשים - תקשרו אותם במהירות: הנחיות התכנסות, הסעות עובדים, חיטוי משטחי עבודה, הדרכות, נוהל חופשות...

7)    צרו ערוץ תקשורת ישיר בין הנהלת החברה לעובדים. ערוץ חד-כיווני שמציג "מידע מתפרץ" ב-Live יכול להיות אחת מהאופציות.

8)    צרו תיבת פניות ייעודית לשאלות ובמידה ויש שאלות חוזרות מומלץ לשלוח לכלל העובדים באופן יזום שאלות ותשובות נפוצות.

 כל ההמלצות והטיפים הללו ניתנים ליישום קל ומהיר באמצעות פלטפורמת Connecteam שמיושמת בעשרות ארגונים בישראל וביניהם: שטראוס, ישרוטל, ניו פארם , תנובה, סודה סטרים, טמבור, כלמוביל, איכילוב, פריגו, מעברות, ויסוצקי, קרסו, פוקס ועוד...

מעוניינים במידע נוסף? – צרו איתי קשר בפרטי.

מנהלים ואנשי HR - הפוסט הזו הוא בשבילכם!

התפרצות נגיף הקורונה משבשת את ההתנהלות היומית באופן משמעותי ולצערנו אנחנו עלולים למצוא את עצמנו בשגרת חירום עוד זמן רב.

לקוחותינו בעולם שיתפו אותנו בדוגמאות כיצד הם מנהלים תקשורת אפקטיבית עם העובדים בעת המשבר ואני שמח לשתף גם אתכם:

המלצות לתקשורת פנים ארגונית נכונה:

1.    שלטו בנרטיב - אל תתנו לעובדים להיות מוזנים ממידע לא אמין ולהניח הנחות שגויות.

2.    אל תתנו לשמועות ו"פייק ניוז" לרוץ בארגון - עצרו את זה כמה שיותר מהר באמצעות תקשורת יזומה ומהירה.

3.    הציגו לעובד את כל הפעולות שאתם עושים כדי לייצר סביבת עבודה בטוחה, זכרו שחלק מהעובדים נמצאים באי ודאות וחשש עקב המידע הרץ ברשת.

4.    ההנחיות בישראל ובמדינות שונות בעולם מתעדכנות ערב-ערב, כיצד זה משפיע על אחרון העובדים ביום למחרת?

שאלות שעובדים מעלים ויש צורך לספק מענה ארגוני:

1.    איך אני יודע שהחברה עושה מה שצריך כדי להגן עלי?

2.    מה יקרה אם ימצאו מישהו חולה בחברה?

3.    מה הנהלים לגבי ימי חופש? מחלה? מה יקרה עם השכר במקרה כזה?

4.   מה אני עושה אם יש לי או לבני משפחתי חשש להידבקות?

6.    איך אני יודע שקולגות שלי לא נשאים?

7.    מה קורה עם הפרויקט שלי/ אירועי החברה?
 
לאופן שבו המידע יתוקשר לעובדים ישנה חשיבות רבה, לכך אתייחס בפוסט הבא...

במידה ותרצו להתייעץ  לגבי תקשורת-פנים אפקטיבית, אתם מוזמנים ליצור איתי קשר בפרטי.

Let's put it out loud and clear: companies' massive layoffs are not a reflection of employees' individual performances.

Thousands of super talented and high performing professionals are being let go by companies week after week and these people are out there looking for their next career opportunity. If you're hiring, you should feel very lucky right now!

Regardless of the impact those people had been driving in their companies, they were still affected by the layoffs. Let's not confuse people's merit with businesses' top down decisions.

It's time to share some love for the ones that are in need now and support each other in the best ways we can. We got this!

Working in operations can sometimes make you feel like one of Beyoncé's sound system staff.  You know that her show would not be as good as it is without you yet nobody is waiting outside for your autograph.  

As an operational leader, I make it my mission to give specific individual credit where credit is due.  Yes, I have an outstanding operational team but rarely do I refer to our successes as solely a team accomplishment.  It's important to call out those individual contributions.  This should be done not only in the team setting but in every space across the organization where it is relevant.  

It's not enough that people know your team is doing well.  As a people leader, I feel it is my privilege to promote my team, their skills, and their accomplishments.  This creates confidence across the organization and sets a positive expectation for future collaborative work.  I want those working with me to be first in line when new career opportunities arise.  When I see a lot of promotions coming from a specific team, I immediately have respect for that leader.  And the cherry on top is that this practice always attracts top talent to your team.  I've always been able to fill my roles with the highest quality individuals.  

Investing your time and intention into the future of others is the best ROI strategy in life and business.

It has been a month since I got news about my position at Pipedrive getting redundant. The company sponsored my residency in Estonia, which now expires because of losing that job. After working here for two years, Estonia gave me three months to find a new one, and I thought I'll share my statistics for the past month.

I sent 76 applications:
• 38 of them are still awaiting a reply;
• 27 applications were either rejected or happened to be not a fit for both parties.

A ton of effort went into polishing my CV:
• it helped me get 20 interviews;
• 3 applications are now in the second stage.

Three months is barely enough to get a job, any job. Massive layoffs, Christmas, and companies reviewing their budget for the following year. I also can't get a remote job or apply to early-stage start-ups because, to stay, I need visa sponsorship. Actively applying, I also prepare plans B, C, and D on how not to return to Russia. I am open to relocating, too. 

Writing this post, I am hoping to feed LinkedIn algorithms and increase engagement. My gratitude to my network is endless. The response my first post got left me speechless and filled with joy. If I could ask you one thing, it would be to comment, as this seems to give extra points in the LinkedIn world. Here's to more positive statistics a month from now!

#opentowork #productdesigner #designsystems

LinkedIn: a quick reminder to those who are still on their #JobSearch or recently got laid off during the holidays..

You are going to make it. There are so many people who are willing to help on this platform. How do you find them? Engage in conversation by sending people who you’ve connected with "Thank You" note.

Especially since Thanksgiving just passed, this is the PERFECT time to say thank you to someone who's helped you throughout your job search or life in general!
💡 Send a thank you to your mentors who have guided you throughout the job process
💡 Send a thank you to your friends who have supported you throughout your journey
💡 Send a thank you to your manager if they've helped you learn more about your own aspirations

A simple thank you goes a long way! Thank you to all of you here on LinkedIn who's following/connected with me. You all are the best ☺️

To all my friends and colleagues - this might be a hard pill of truth to swallow. Keep reading if you care about your and your beloved ones' future:
For decades, the propaganda against Israel has forced us Israelis to hold back our thoughts and refrain from expressing our frustration about what we already knew - we were facing a group of people that opposes everything we believe in and genuinely wants to eliminate our existence from the earth.

When we did express our truth, we were labeled as "racists," "oppressors," or "apartheid supporters" by some in the U.S. and in Europe. This trend has intensified in recent years to a point where, even after the horrific events in Israel where women were raped beside their friends' dead bodies, when children were murdered next to their parents in their own homes, and civilians were kidnapped, yesterday there were protests celebrating those horrific events in NYC, SF, Chicago, Seattle, London, Rotterdam, Barcelona, Sydney, and other cities around the world, most of these protests are chanting for the destruction of Israel.

There's one thing you need to know - today it's Israel, tomorrow it could be your city, your country. This type of hatred extends beyond Jew-hatred or anti-Israel type of hatred; it transcends the geographical borders of the Middle East - targeting Christians, women, gays, and any western civilization. It's already present in the U.S., Europe and Australia.

What can you do? Stand up to the bigotry! Regardless of political views, one should denounce this hatred and be vocal about it. Silence is what they desire, just like they did to us. Never again.
We the People

החדשות הטובות 🤠: נראה ששוק ההייטק מתעורר. בשבועות האחרונים בעודי מחפשת עבודה כמנהלת מוצר באופן אקטיבי, ניכר כי היצע המשרות עלה, וכך גם אחוז הפניות והתהליכים שהתחלתי. אז למרות שנראה שכל יומיים מתפרסמת ידיעה על חברה שמפטרת או נסגרת, עדיין יש לא מעט חברות טובות שמגייסות ״על אמת״ (ולא מעלות סתם ׳משרות רפאים׳). אני אומרת את זה בהשוואה ללפני 4 חודשים כשחיפשתי על אש קטנה בעודי עובדת, סתם כדי לדגום את השוק. נכון, זה לא מדגם מייצג, אבל קצת אופטימיות אף פעם לא תזיק.

החדשות הפחות טובות 🫠: אני עדיין בחיפושים לתפקיד הבא שלי כמנהלת מוצר. אני מביאה שנתיים של ניסיון במקצוע, ועוד 6 שנים של ידע רחב ומגוון שספגתי בעודי מסקרת את עולם ההייטק והטכנולגיה.

כעת אני הולכת לבקש מכם משהו שמאוד מאוד קשה לי, אבל כנראה שאני צריכה להתאים את עצמי לפלטפורמה שבה אני נמצאת. אז, אם יש לכם שנייה פנויה, אשמח אם תוכלו לתת לפוסט שלי קצת ״אהבה דיגיטלית״ באמצעות לייק, תגובה, או שיתוף, כדי לעזור לי למקסם את כוחו של האלגוריתם, ובתקווה להגיע ככה לאנשים הנכונים שמחפשים מישהי כמוני.

🫶 תודה

The good news 🤠: During my active job search as a product manager over the past few weeks, I have noticed a significant increase in job opportunities, inquiries, and the number of recruitment processes I have initiated. Despite the frequent news about companies closing down or laying off employees, there are still several genuine job openings available in good companies. While this might not be a comprehensive representation, having a little optimism can't hurt.

The not-so-great news 🫠: I am still on the hunt for my next job as a product manager. I have two years of experience in the field, along with an additional 6 years of extensive and varied relevant knowledge that I have gained while working as a tech reporter.

Hi everyone, after 18 months of hard work, I'm excited to announce that today we finally launched Twingate to the world. 
If you're still using VPN today, you're likely leaving yourself open to the potential of broad network attack through lateral movement and an exposed public gateway. 

Twingate creates a step function improvement in security while also making remote access for users and administrators alike incredibly easy—you can sign up for free on our website. We're also live on Hacker News today, look for "Twingate" if you'd like to upvote us.
#cybersecurity #remoteaccess #vpn

Have you seen the latest update from the hill? CMS announced a new initiative, Patients Over Paperwork—a call to the industry to help determine what provider regulations it should junk or revamp. And I think this is awesome—yes, providers have way too much regulatory work, and of course it’s affecting clinical outcomes and patient interactions and slowing HIT innovation. athenahealth has been all over this for twenty years now, digging into our data to figure out where providers and staff are hurting most and how we can free them up. We’re getting close, and CMS is on the right track—but we’ve got to do a lot more than roll back regulations if we want to relieve the burnout epidemic and bring humanity back to healthcare.

Where do you think regulations hurt the most? What needs to
happen next?

I have a gatekeeper and I am impossible to reach through the phone or email if you are trying to sell me something.  I would like to announce that I just had my first meeting with someone who reached out to me on Linked In.  Not only did I take the meeting but I bought the product!  Are you dying to know how he broke through?  He called me from Israel.  I thought it was a scam so I texted back with "Sorry, I can't talk right now." He texted me and said "Hi Kristina, I'll be in DC next week Friday from abroad and would like to meet to discuss partnership."  I texted back with "What is your name?"  He replied: "Matthew Cohen, we connected on Linked In."  So I checked out his profile and read about his company HEREMobility and I agreed to meet.  Not only was it a great meeting but we had so much in common!  He lives in Israel but I detected a South African accent.  I was the only person he had ever met that recognized his accent.  I lived in South Africa before he was born of course in 1976-78.  I am sure we will be lifelong friends. #HEREMobility #Matthewcohen #salesisaboutrelationships #startupnation #artificialintelligence #breakingthruthegatekeeper #restonlimo

I won SDR of the year 3x

Most months I was at the top of the leaderboard for quota attainment

However, I was never at the top of the activity boards

I never won competitions for making the most dials

I didn't use automated cadences

In fact, I was usually near the bottom of the activity boards

So how did I see success with such low volume?

Because I focused on 3 things:

1. High-quality outreach
2. Multi-channel follow-up
3. Solving one problem at a time

Reps get caught up focusing their time on the wrong things

Needing to be the "top caller" for the day or sending the most emails are a quick ride to burn out

Focus on the inputs, not the outputs 💙

I shared this with someone in a comment, but I figured it's worth throwing into a quick post.

I'm a big fan of backup plans. Before I was laid off early this year, I'd seen the writing on the wall and started a list of backup plans: who I could reach out to, part-time work I could pick up, places I could seek out opportunities. 

One of these "keep in your back pocket" plans was looking for "bridge" work - for some people that's finding a retail or serving job, but that doesn't work for everyone (have you seen childcare costs?!). 

There are tons of remote jobs out there, many of them supporting call centers or similar. It's not glamorous work and it's a pay cut for laid-off tech folks, but it could be the difference between paying your bills or not. 

So with that, here are a ton of Facebook groups I've come across that share these types of roles (and some share higher-level ones as well!). I'm not vouching for anything here, your mileage may vary, etc. etc. but feel free to use this as a resource if it's helpful.

It's hard out there for jobseekers. 

Don't make it harder on yourself.

I see too many people trying to skirt the standard process in an effort to "stand out," but that only works when it's very, very well executed.

And most of the time, it isn't. 

Not long ago I received an email to my personal address, apropos of nothing, from a complete stranger. I was one of - no joke - probably 100 people listed in the "to" line. The email included a resume and a pitch for why I (or the 99 other recipients) should hire this person. 

What's wrong with this tactic?

Putting aside all mention of "personal email" and "public recipient list," there was no context. There was zero information about how this person got my info, what they think I'm hiring for, or why they're a fit for that specific position. In fact, I don't even recruit for the level of role they're seeking and I haven't in years. 

It's about as effective as printing 100 copies of your resume and mailing them to addresses from the phonebook. 

Instead, take the time to be at least a little intentional. I don't expect anyone to write me a totally personalized email, but I do need some context. Before contacting hundreds of people, make sure they're actually folks who could help you. And yeah, sometimes form letters are way more efficient than not, but at least do a mail merge so it's less obvious (and preserves privacy).

Update:  this is not a salary or full time position. Please note that you do not need an LLC to participate.

What's your SPOOKIEST job interview story? 

I have a few that come to mind.

1. The interviewers were very insistent on telling me that it was a very quiet office. Like, "No one really talks here" quiet. 

If you know me at all, you would understand the abject HORROR I felt in that moment. 😱 And also my extreme lack of surprise when I did not get that job. 

2. The interviewer, who was also the head of the company, felt it important to question me on why I'd leave my current job, given that there was free soda. This interview also included a discussion about my SAT scores. Truly terrifying.

Share your frightening tales in the comments. ⬇️

👻👻👻

I worked with a client last week on some interview prep, but when the interview happened, they felt like it didn't go as well as it could have. This client is making a bit of a career transition, and while they were prepared, they felt caught off guard by a few more technical questions. 

They chalked it up to a good learning experience and useful data about what to expect next time.

Until they got a job offer THE NEXT DAY. 🎉

The moral of the story: we are our own worst critics. Even when you've done the work and you go in prepared, you might feel unsure or critical of your performance. 

But no one is perfect, and even if you stumble or know you could've done even better, you could still be the right person for the job. Don't count yourself out prematurely!

Sometimes you fail. 

You spend most of your career as a top performer, known for getting the job done and done well. Making it look easy. 

You rise a few ranks, to the exact point where you're no longer exceptional, maybe not even good. You know, the Peter Principal. 

The perfect opportunity with just the right amount of long-term growth suddenly requires that growth from you immediately. Against your intuition you follow the steps laid out before you without doing your due diligence; it's the first time you don't have institutional knowledge to rely on and you don't learn enough fast enough.

And then the way you show up, or the way you're perceived, isn't quite up to par. It would be better if you were replaced by someone else, or just not there at all. 

Maybe you agree. Maybe you don't, and you rail against it, fighting tooth and nail against this belief that's in such opposition to what you know of yourself. Maybe an identity crisis ensues, maybe your imposter syndrome laughs and says "I told you so," maybe you simply busy yourself with all the resultant loose ends that need tying up. 

There isn't a do-over; there's no time or space for that. There's only the future and the chance to let this serve as propulsion forward. An opportunity to take the worthwhile lessons—trust yourself, share louder, speak up, ask for help—and leave the rest. Let it crush you if you have to until you're ready to build back up. 

So yeah, sometimes you fail and it sucks.

But you should talk about it. Acknowledge it. Share it.

We all should.

Salary transparency laws are supposed to be a good thing...but in some ways, they've actually caused more confusion.

And I think every workplace should be educating their workforce on how compensation works - both within their company and more broadly. 

But sadly, for so long compensation has been treated as something secretive and there's been so little education that even some recruiters may not really understand the laws, how their company sets compensation, etc. 

1. So first, the laws:
Most of the laws I've read around this ask companies to publish a minimum and a maximum - a starting salary is insufficient. 
But they don't define what those numbers represent. They say things like "reasonable minimum and maximum" (NY) and the minimum and maximum the company will reference in setting the salary (CT). 

So the safest, least risky thing a company is going to do is publish the true minimum and maximum for the role that they have published internally. 

And this is how we end up with broad ranges like $120k-250k for a role. That IS the salary range for the role. Someone with that title at the company COULD be paid any of these numbers. But it's rare they will HIRE across that full range.

2. The company's compensation philosophy
Every company philosophy drives how they set that salary range, what companies/industries they benchmark against, where they position themselves in the market, how they place someone within the range, what factors are considered, etc. 

Some companies benchmark against similar companies and want to pay at or above market value to secure and retain top talent. 
Some may set their ranges lower within the market, and often these are companies willing to train more or may try to make up for it with bonus/equity, etc.

3. There is generally going to be a hiring range that is within but doesn't encompass the full salary range. That's where the intend to place new hires. 
Why isn't the full range available? 
Because most companies aren't going to pay unproven talent top dollar. 
They aren't paying above market value for someone who hasn't delivered results for them. And your first 3-6 months (sometimes more) you are costing the company more than you are earning them in most cases...so they need to account for that in your compensation. 

Criteria for setting within that salary range can include years of experience, degrees, certifications, location, performance in the interview, etc. 

Some industries are pretty standardized - think teaching, government, union jobs. There's a strict formula based on objective criteria, or everyone starts at the same place. 

Others will consider a variety of the criteria above to set the starting salary. 

IMO, these laws should ALSO require companies to share this context on the posting (I'll drop examples in comments).

But many don't so you can and should expect a recruiter to discuss the hiring range with you - and don't be surprised if it's narrower than the publicized range!

It feels wrong for companies to offer remote work but only to those who live outside a certain radius. Either employees can work effectively while remote or they can't - it shouldn't be related to their location. 

I'm seeing a lot of "if you're within 50 miles, we expect you in the office 3-5 days a week, but if you're 51+ miles away, you can be 100% remote." 

I just don't see how it makes sense. If you're requiring hybrid/onsite for "culture" or "collaboration," aren't you saying those outside a 50-mile radius are therefore missing out on something important? Or, if you acknowledge that a distributed team works just fine, why force people into the office just because of proximity? 🤔

(I know, I know - it's because of commercial real estate costs/requirements from local governments/etc., but that doesn't mean I think it is reasonable.)

I know plenty of people who have been laid off this year, and I’m starting to see their jobs opening back up. I didn't anticipate how frustrated I would feel to see a 𝘧𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘥'𝘴 former job reposted after a layoff. 

(I mean, seeing my 𝘰𝘸𝘯 former job reposted was a gut punch, but I was expecting that.)

It’s an important reminder that while we all want to love our work and do the best job we can, a job can't love us back. It's just business. Admittedly, I’ve always found the “if you died, your company would post your job the next day” expression a little callous — surely they wouldn’t literally post it that quickly if you 𝘥𝘪𝘦𝘥. But at the end of the day, we 𝘢𝘳𝘦 all replaceable to the workplace.

On the other hand, we’re NOT replaceable to our children, pets, partners, parents, friends, houseplants, whatever (okay, maybe any plant I come in contact with would like to replace me #deadbrownthumb). Business decisions are business decisions and ultimately it doesn't matter why they were made. It's not worth taking personally. 

It is worth it, however, to cultivate the relationships in your life & the things that bring you joy. That's what you'll look back on someday and cherish, not meetings and commutes.

There's a lot of talk about how frustrating it is to be a "perfect fit" for a job, yet still end up rejected. Folks are convinced this is due to "ATS bots" that don't understand how to assess a candidate's true fit. 

That's not true. As a recruiter, there's lot that goes into candidate assessment.

First, we get info from the hiring team. Recruiters don't decide what to look for; we base our search on criteria from the hiring managers. In this market, hiring teams are looking for folks who have done the job before + are an exact fit. 

When a resume comes in, I'll first see if the applicant's in the right location. Even remote jobs have location requirements: if a company only hires in the US, we can't consider someone in Europe. If your background is 100% in line but you're outside the US, it's a no-go.

Then I look at questions answered in the application. For example, if you said NO to "do you have US work authorization?", and the company doesn't sponsor/transfer visas, we'll decline. 

From there, I look at years of experience. If the candidate just finished undergrad but is applying for a Staff Engineer role, the buck stops here. If they're on the cusp, sometimes something in their background makes them competitive. In this market, though, there are plenty of candidates with the exact experience required, so there's less need for recruiters to argue for those who don't. 

Then it's time to assess the details. As an engineering example, if a hiring team wants a Staff Engineer with extensive Java experience, that's what I look for. If the candidate is in the right location + has 15 years of experience but hasn't touched Java? Unfortunately, it's a no. Yes, they can learn it, but when there are other candidates who are experts, we'll to speak with them first.

If the hiring team wants a backend expert, we focus on folks with that expertise. An engineer whose resume is focused on the frontend won't move forward.

There are plenty of other things we look at + they vary by company/team. Does the resume display the person's achievements or is it vague? Can we get a feel for the type of projects they've completed? Is it clear what they *want* to do? Do the sizes + stages of their past companies align with this one? Do they have a habit of only staying at jobs for three months? 

NONE of this has any bearing on whether the candidate COULD do the job. It just means their experience doesn't match up 100% with the requirements or their resume doesn't adequately reflect their skills. 

In a different job market, it's another situation. When it's hard to find candidates, hiring teams are more open to folks with transferrable skills or who would have to learn on the job.

So the next time you find yourself wondering why you didn't make the cut, remember that the process involves *many* layers of evaluation and it's not personal. 

#resumereview #candidateassessment #jobsearchtips #jobsearching #atsresume

This week was busy with an ATS implementation, but led me to a funny realization. 

The new ATS we are using seems pretty sleek and has a decent reputation with recruiters. 

But the funny part is that this is the 7th ATS I've worked in as a recruiter. Across those 7 I still haven't seen any;

- Automatic Candidate Rankings
- Automatic Rejections
- Automatic Keyword Scanning and Ranking

Honestly, I can't even say all 7 have automatically HIGHLIGHTED keywords. 

All these horror stories of ATS automation feel like bigfoot at this point. I've heard so much about it but have never seen it in real life. 

Is there value in doing some up front resume work? Absolutely. 

Clarity, relevancy, impact, readability, and conciseness are all important aspects of a successful resume that you can be thoughtful around.

What you don't need to think about is how to beat the ATS bot. It doesn't exist. 

All 7 ATS so far have still required humans to look at them. 

Worry less about beating an ATS bot and more about capturing a human's attention.

Things change so rapidly that I'm sure there are plenty of sites out there I'm not even aware of, so would love to hear from folks!

It's weird out there, y'all. 

I talk to all sorts of people who have great experience, a resume that conveys that experience well, and a robust network. 

They're still struggling to get traction in the job search. 

Right now, even technical roles are inundated with hundreds or even thousands of applications. There's no realistic way for a recruiter or hiring manager to speak to every one of them. 

A lot of people would say you should message everyone at the company or film and send a video with each application. That's...a thing you could do. 

But my advice? Be creative, and I don't mean in the video sense. 

If you can afford it, take some time for family or a passion project. If you need an imminent cash flow, what can bridge the gap? Freelance or consulting work? A job outside of your field? Taking on gig work or childcare? 

When I started suspecting I'd be laid off, I made a list of backup plans. Some I've turned into regular parts of my work life - writing, consulting - and others are still in the back of my mind.  

You don't have to completely exit the job search, but finding a plan for the meantime may let you focus your effort on the roles you're really qualified for and the companies where you have an "in." 

And you never know - you may meet people along the way who help you find that next right job.

There's probably a reason you didn't get the job. 

And chances are, it isn't a lack of qualifications. 

I've seen it time and time again as both a recruiter & a candidate: a perfect matchup of qualifications and experience, but no job. 🚫

Why?

▪️There's a single job available & someone else was an even better fit. For example, you meet the basic requirements but another candidate meets those *and* all the preferred requirements. 
▪️Your resume showed that you met the qualifications, but you didn't convey them well in your interview (too vague, poor examples, suboptimal solutions, etc.). 
▪️You communicated poorly (too long-winded or off-topic).
▪️You expressed concerns about the pay, location, or hours, but the company can't make any changes.
▪️You entered the process when others were nearing the end, and a different candidate received an offer.
▪️You didn't show any interest in the organization or the role itself.
▪️You were rude, arrogant, or inappropriate (yeah, this does happen...thankfully, it's rare.)

Hiring isn't a perfect science. Hiring teams don't always get it right, but more often than not we have to choose from a pool of qualified candidates & unfortunately we can't hire everyone. 

Don't take it personally. Grab what you can learn from it & move on to the next thing - the right opportunity is out there.

So, this business about posting a fake job on LinkedIn so you can collect resumes and then copy them and be more attractive for jobs?

I have a better idea.

First, don't. 

Not only is it fraudulent and a bad use of people's personal information, it isn't useful. So you get resumes, but that doesn't tell you if they're good. It doesn't give you any evidence about whether the person would be hired.

Instead, try actually using LinkedIn for its intended purpose. Look up people in the job you want and check out their profile. Connect with them and ask if they have any tips for you. They may even be willing to share their resume.

I know - it's a little more work & a lot less fraud, but sometimes we just have to take one for the team (& try something that may actually be helpful). 🤷‍♀️

Most people think that resumes are really complicated, but they don't have to be.

A resume = a marketing document that sells your work.

Want a really quick & easy resume audit? Here ya go:

✔️ Does your resume show a way to get in touch? Email, phone, & LinkedIn are ideal. Add a portfolio or Github link if those are relevant. 
✔️ Did you include your current job and relevant roles from the past ~10 years?
✔️ Does each role include bullet points (which are easier to read than long paragraphs)?
✔️ Does each bullet begin with a verb (e.g. "created, managed, implemented" instead of "responsible for")?
✔️ Are your tenses accurate? Use past tense for past jobs or work you've completed, and present tense for current work.
✔️ Do most bullets display tangible results? 
✔️ Are these results relevant to the job for which you're applying? For example, a recruiter moving into sales might incorporate less detail about screening and interviewing, and more about exceeding their quota and hunting for leads.
✔️ Are your bullets as objective as possible? Avoid subjective content like "great time management" or "good team player."
✔️ Is your resume easy to read? Think simple: no tables or graphics or charts needed. Basic fonts are best, and some color is fine but don't go overboard. 
✔️ Is your education included, if applicable? 
✔️ Have you included relevant volunteer work? 

If you can check all these boxes, you're in good shape. You don't need to be fancy; a resume is about the content itself, not necessarily the package. You want to show that your past experience qualifies you for whatever the next step is.

This is a story about my dog, but it's also a story about remote work. 

My dog died last week. I couldn't be more devastated and I also couldn't be more grateful for the ten years we had with her, especially the last three years being able to be work from home with her. 

Amidst all the condolences we've received (ask me another day about how losing a pet is just as significant of a loss as losing a human), we've received some flowers. 

🌼 Flowers from my parents.
🌼 Flowers from our next door neighbors, who always wanted to steal our dog (you know who you are 👀 🤣 ). 
🌼 Flowers from our nanny, who works in our home. 
🌼 And flowers from a former coworker, who I have yet to meet in "real life" - but with whom I have just as strong of a connection as if I had. 

My point (aside from wanting an excuse to talk about my dog): I'm seeing a lot lately about the idea that teams can only truly form a connection in person, but I believe remote teams can be just as strong as onsite teams. You can build just as much of a connection - both professionally and personally.

Plus, not being in an office meant I could spend more time with Daisy in her last days. And someday I'll have another dog, and I'll be darned if I spend all my time away from them commuting to an office full time. 

#remotework #dogs #workfromhome

One of the biggest issues I have with so many companies forcing RTO for jobs that can be done remotely is this: it takes opportunities away from anyone who can't or won't relocate.

Here's what I mean. I'm in Seattle, which is pretty heavily positioned as a tech town. The tech industry is, uh, going through some things right now 🫠, with a lot of the major Seattle employers laying off rather than hiring. Lots of people have to consider employers who are based outside the Seattle area.

If most of those employers are requiring onsite work, the options are... relocate or remain unemployed. Now, didn't people used to move for work all the time? Sure did. (In fact, my dad's job relocating our family is how I ended up in Seattle to begin with). 

But that was then. Without even getting into the fact that things cost a lot more now & housing is a LOT harder to come by... who is going to be comfortable relocating when companies are laying people off left & right, often completely unexpectedly, even after huge hiring sprees?

If a company can't offer any sort of loyalty, how can they expect people to relocate and uproot their lives? 
 
Better idea: Companies, let people work where it makes sense for them. Save money by not paying a relocation stipend. Build a more diverse workforce by hiring wherever the best candidate is instead of limiting yourself to whoever already lives near your office. And...although it pains me to say it, if you decide you truly do need someone in the office, you'll have a lot more success getting people to move closer once you've proven you value your employees (not advocating for a bait & switch here, people).

#FridayFeelings #remotework #rto

I see a lot of confusion about these terms, so here's a quick & simple breakdown (#NotALawyer):

‼️ 𝐑𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤: This is a law, found in ~27 U.S. states, that dictates that an employee's job security cannot be predicated upon their joining or paying dues to a labor union. It has nothing to do with why someone can or cannot be fired (unless they're in danger of termination for not joining a union). Rather, it provides employees the "right to work" even if they don't wish to join a union. 

‼️ 𝐀𝐭-𝐖𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐄𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐲𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭: This is a law in almost every state in the U.S., with Montana being the sole outlier. At-will employment means that an employer can terminate an employee at any time, for any reason, provided that reason isn't discriminatory against a protected class. It also affords employees the right to terminate the employment relationship at any time, for any reason. There are other laws that impact the way large-scale layoffs are handled (like WARN), but for the most part you or your employer can sever ties easily. 


#employmentlaws  #righttowork #atwillemployment #themoreyouknow #hr

Leaders:

If you can't trust employees to be productive while working a remote or flexible schedule, remote work isn't the problem. Lack of trust is.

Have they given you a reason not to trust their work/productivity? Manage them.

Is there no evidence of a problem beyond your own fear of not being able to watch them work? Manage yourself.

It's pretty simple.

 #remotework #productivity

🔥 𝐇𝐨𝐭 𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞: CEOs aren't requiring a return to office to foster connectivity, but because leading a truly remote/distributed workforce is 𝘩𝘢𝘳𝘥 - at least if you want to do it well.

An article from CNBC articulates a lot of what I've been thinking. Quoting a director at Upwork, it reads: 

"She says working during the pandemic wasn’t working remotely as much as it was working through crisis in a remote setting. 'This is making it work because you have to,' she explains, 'but the real long-term work of building out policies and practices that actually keep people happy, keep them working at your company and not looking for another job, and keep them productive is a long process.'"

Yup. It's hard to manage a distributed team. But giving your employees the flexibility to decide how they work best is worth the challenge, in my opinion. And I say this as someone who had to learn very quickly to manage a fairly large, very distributed team - it's not easy, but it pays off.

A word of unsolicited advice / #themoreyouknow 🌠 : recruiters don't find jobs for people. 

I know, the job of a recruiter seems to be "getting people into jobs," so why not? 

Well, there are two categories of recruiter: internal and external.

Internal recruiters work for a specific company and fill jobs only for that organization. Often, those recruiters are dedicated to a specific part of the business, like sales or G&A or tech. 

External recruiters work for a third-party (or themselves) and support clients in filling specific jobs. They may have a speciality (e.g. tech or executive roles).

In all cases, if there isn't a job opening on that recruiter's desk that matches your background, they won't be of much use in your search. 

You may be thinking, "okay, but if a recruiter finds a great candidate, why can't they just find a way to get them hired to a role anyway?"

For an external recruiter, it's because they won't get paid. If no one has said, "We want to give you money to fill XYZ role," a recruiter is not going to go out of their way to present a candidate and try to find a place for them -- unless they're using that candidate as a way to try and drum up business, which is often not overly successful. While this may seem unkind, we all work for money, and hustling to find a spot for a candidate - for free - means potentially missing out on paid work. 

An internal recruiter may be able to introduce you to a colleague who works on relevant roles, but - because they only work for the one company - there's nothing they can do if there isn't an open role.

Is this annoying and frustrating? Absolutely. In a perfect world, most of us recruiters would LOVE to help all job seekers find their next dream job - but at present, it's just not in the cards for most of us. 

(There is something called "reverse recruiting" wherein you can hire someone to do exactly this, but I don't have personal experience using such a service and can't comment on the process or quality.)

#recruiting #jobsearch #hiring

Just a reminder that laid off ≠ fired. I keep seeing the terms used interchangeably in articles (this morning's was about the expected Meta layoffs), and while it seems like petty semantics, it's an important distinction.

You're fired if you are somehow at fault (even in an innocuous way, like not meeting the standards of the job even though you tried). A layoff is due to a company decision to reduce headcount, often (but not always) for budgetary reasons. 

A small thing, maybe, but language matters.

There's a lot of misinformation circulating about how ATS works. 

So it's time for me to set the record straight again.

Let's get started!

➡️ An ATS is just an electronic filing system for job applications. Nothing more, nothing less. 

➡️ There isn't a single ATS. Instead, there are hundreds of different systems. Many companies use a commercial 3rd party system whereas larger companies like Google and FB develop and manage their own ATS. 

➡️ You can't "get past" or "beat" an ATS. Once you submit your application, you're inside the ATS for that company. Which is where you want to be. Being inside the system allows you to be considered for the job you applied for as well as other positions (more on that in a bit). 

➡️ There are no "ATS bots" that scan your resume for keywords when you upload it and reject you if you don't have the correct keywords. None. Zero. Zip. ATS bots simply do not exist. 

➡️ Instead, it is (almost) ALWAYS a human who will review your resume and decide whether or not you're a good fit.

➡️ Sometimes you will get rejected immediately based on what are known as "knockout questions". Knockout questions are questions that you respond to as part of the application process. These are generally yes/no questions such as "Are you legally allowed to work in the US?".  If you answer "no", you'll be knocked out for that job. BUT you'll still be inside of the ATS which allows you to be considered for other jobs that have different requirements. 

➡️ Recruiters also use the ATS for sourcing. This is where they actively search for candidates who might be a good fit for a role that they're about to open. They will enter keywords into the ATS (e.g., job titles, hard skills), often using Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT). This is why you want to be INSIDE the ATS: it allows you to be considered for roles that you didn't even apply for. 

Hope this helps you better understand how ATS works!!!

I've seen more new job announcements in my feed today than I have in months. 🙌 

Even amidst new layoffs every day, people *are* getting hired. 

Yes, even recruiters!

I've been pretty lucky in my career to work for companies that tried to treat candidates well; we weren't always perfect (and one of my past employers was indeed guilty of using Workday with its obnoxious 7000-click process), but we tried to make it easy and efficient. 

I'd forgotten how wild it is out here, though - I started then skipped one application asking me whether I was a pirate or an Imperial Naval Officer and another that asked no fewer than seven essay questions. 

This one, I did finish applying to, but... why this question? Why is this part of the application? How is this relevant to my recruiting leadership skills?WHO CARES?! 

#AdventuresInJobHunting #AndroidForLife

Where my recruiters at?

...and what's your plan?! 🤷‍♀️

I was asked by a fellow recruiter yesterday whether it's better to stay in the field and deal with the economic extremes or find a different career path. 

The current economic situation is truly like nothing I've ever (personally) seen, and it's hard to imagine how/when TA jobs will be in demand again. With large-scale layoffs still happening daily, it will be a while before most companies are hiring enough to need additional recruiters. But for many of us, being in recruiting long enough pretty much means you'll only ever be considered for... jobs in recruiting. 

So it raises the question: what are our options? If you're a displaced recruiter or TA leader, what is your backup plan? What would you suggest for someone looking to find a new path? If you've pivoted out of recruiting, how did you do it?

I'm envisioning some sort of program to retrain displaced recruiters into other career paths using the myriad transferable skills we have, but until someone brings that into reality, we'll need to figure it out ourselves. 

#recruiting #recruiters #talentacquisition #careerchange #careerpivot #retraining

When things in our lives seem to go wrong, we often feel like it’s the end of the world because we can’t see further than what’s right in front of us. However, it is only when we look back after we’ve survived the storm that we realize that those “broken” parts are pieces that make up the beautiful picture of our destiny.

Sometimes, things need to fall apart for everything to come together because not getting what we want can be a huge step toward reaching a bigger dream, according to Rachel Brathen.

Obstacles and rejections are merely stepping stones to something great, but you must change your attitude and not take rejection personally. Instead, redirect your rejection and use it for something good; will it be easy? Hell no, but it will be worth it in the end because we are never rejected, only redirected.

It's a blessing and a curse to be perceptive, to know how to read between the lines and see what isn't being said outright. Knowing that 2 + 2 = 4 and the math is right there waiting for someone to add it up. 

It's a blessing because you can do what you need to, prepare yourself, gather up loose ends. A curse because then you have to deal with what's coming without the bliss of ignorance. Anticipatory grief, anxiety, all of that.

But in the knowing there's some level of safety. Articles are now coming out about "career cushioning," the apparently-novel idea of seeing the writing on the wall and opening yourself to opportunities before you need them. You live through one recession and you start to know the story, so saving money and cultivating your network and thinking about your next move become second nature.

All of this to say: HubSpot laid off a small percentage of employees today and I was one of them. While I saw it coming (I mean I called it *to the very day*), I was still (unfortunately, embarrassingly) surprised to *actually* be included. I won't get into how something like this affects one's confidence but if you know, you know. It's jarring.

So here we are. The blessing part of this is the conversations already underway, gradually-curated lists of "job loss plans" and "side hustle ideas" to go through, & thoughts about what's next and how to use this time. 

But first, a reminder: work is not your identity. A job is not your family. The people, they might be; I've made friends at HubSpot that I hope I'll have for life. I've learned a lot and it was probably the best job I've ever had. But at the end of the day, you have to look out for yourself. You have to be ready. And you have to remember what's truly important (no, you won't look back on your life & wish you'd worked more). Control what you can, cultivate what matters, do your own bit of saving.

It's difficult to see daily layoff announcements, full stop. It's made especially devastating by the fact that seemingly just yesterday we were in a boom time. It feels like we're experiencing whiplash from such a sudden change.

But --

That's exactly the thing. While the recent prosperity seems to have slowed, the tech industry WAS extremely prosperous until recently. But just a couple years ago was the great shutdown of 2020 - and things bounced back into the recent boom we all experienced. A decade and a half ago we struggled through the Great Recession, but things bounced back. Twenty years ago the dot com bubble exploded, but... things bounced back. 

It's easy to get lost in the stress and anxiety of change (and by all means, losing one's job truly is one of life's most stressful experiences). But after every downturn, there's been an upswing. Change is the only constant, and just as we rapidly fell into troubling times, eventually we'll see the other side again.

I remember - vaguely, without the detail of who said what but with incredible recollection of how it made me feel - the first time someone at work acknowledged seeing a therapist. I was early in my career and equally early in my ~mental health journey~, still afraid to admit to seeing a mental health provider. 

Having it normalized by someone more experienced in both life + career was huge. In the nearly-two decades since (😬👵), it's become more and more acceptable to speak up about our mental health, but there's still so much further to go. 

There's a term sometimes used at HubSpot - "leaving loudly" - that indicates sharing publicly that you're taking time off, going on vacation, or otherwise out of office; the idea is to normalize taking a break. I choose to "therapy loudly," keeping those appointments on my calendar, viewable to anyone who happens to be calendar stalking. It's a small thing, but if it helps anyone feel less alone, it's a win. 

We don't feel secretive about getting an annual physical or seeing a doctor about a broken leg -- it's just healthcare. Mental health is just as important, so let's bring it into the light.

There's a lot of advice floating around the internet about how to network while job hunting. One big suggestion I often hear is to contact someone at the company to "get your resume in front of a person" and "beat the ATS." ATS fear-mongering aside (bots aren't throwing out your resume), I'd like to share some quick advice. 

It can be a great idea to contact someone at the company - but there are a few things to consider:

1️⃣  Are you a fit for the job? If you don't meet the requirements, just reaching out to someone isn't going to change much, so make sure you're aligned with what the job requires.

2️⃣ Who are you contacting? If it's a recruiter, do they work on this type of role? I receive many messages from prospective candidates who are seeking jobs in sales, marketing, project management - the whole gamut! The thing is, I don't actually own roles as a manager, and I only support the Engineering team. If someone is outside of the realm of Engineering, I can't be much help!

So... how do you get around this? Simple: utilize LinkedIn's search feature. Don't just look for recruiters at [Company] - search for something like "sales recruiter [company]" or "engineering recruiter [company]." Read the profile to make sure the person focuses on the type of role you're going for. Recruiters WANT great candidates, so chances are their profile calls out what roles they tend to work on. Tip: Your best bet is a recruiter, not a recruiting manager or recruiting coordinator - those are different functions that aren't reviewing resumes most of the time. 

And in most cases, the first thing the recruiter will tell you to do is apply online - so take the first step + do it before you reach out!

further context on ✨ the ATS ✨

Tuesday thoughts:

ATS = applicant tracking system; it is a database that tracks applicants throughout the process. In ~15 years of recruiting, I’ve never seen one that actually filters resumes out except when the company inputs disqualifying questions. Ex: the application asks if you have a Master's, you say no & you’re excluded. Most systems just change your status & recruiters can - & should - double check before declining.

Referrals are helpful, but not for the reason people think. It’s not a situation of “get referred, beat the ATS.” At every company where I know recruiters, a human reviews resumes. A referral helps because you’re a known quantity. Someone - ideally who is trusted & respected at the company - vouches for you. 

Yes, in some cases (without OFCCP compliance rules), being referred can get your resume selected even if you otherwise would be declined. That isn’t because of an ATS, but because a recruiter reviews your experience & matches it to what the hiring manager needs. If a recruiter is seeking ten years of experience & an applicant has considerably less, the recruiter will likely move on. If a respected colleague sends that same resume & shares their experience working with the candidate, the recruiter is much more likely to seriously consider them.

Since graduating from college (many years ago 🤣), I've landed six jobs. Of those, four were solely from applying online. One was a referral. One was a hybrid of both (someone referred me to the staffing agency where I could apply online for a Microsoft contract).

My point? While networking is absolutely an important part of the job hunt, it's still worth it to have a compelling, targeted resume and APPLY! Resumes and applications really do get reviewed even if you don't come in as a referral. 

If you see a job posting that excites you, take the leap - you never know if you could be exactly what they're looking for!

𝗥𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘄𝗮𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗲𝗱:

➡️When you applied, other candidates were further along & likely to receive an offer
➡️You meet 𝘮𝘰𝘴𝘵 of the requirements, but others meet 𝘢𝘭𝘭
➡️Your resume states your interest in work that is not this job (e.g. a resume targeting machine learning work submitted to a role that does none)
➡️Your current job is a few levels higher than this one & nothing about your application indicates your interest in this level (e.g. a director applying to an IC role with no context).
➡️You haven't done this exact job before
➡️The role required a cover letter & you didn't submit one, or you 𝘥𝘪𝘥 but it was addressed to the wrong company
➡️You answered questions when applying (set by a recruiter, not a robot) that filtered you out (think: "Are you willing to relocate?" or "How many years of experience do you have?")
➡️There are typos/grammar mistakes 

Note: 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙚 of these equate to, "You are not good enough/deserving of a job." 𝘚𝘰 much of hiring is situational; timing is everything. Time is limited & recruiters can't speak to every applicant, even if we wish we could. We know many applicants 𝘤𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 do the job but we have to focus on those who seem to be the best candidates, at the right time, for the right role.

Recruiters don't run the world (I wish, right?!). While it may seem like we have a lot of power in the hiring process since we're often the main point of contact, we don't make the final decision... and we aren't responsible for company policy. 

I can't tell you how many times I've heard frustration about how recruiters won't share interview feedback, when the truth is, it's (usually) not up to us! 

Now, what *is* in a recruiter's control is whether they get back to you in a timely manner with updates, and it's imperative that this happens. But recruiters are subject to company policy just as much as everyone else, and policies around sharing interview feedback are often set by HR or Legal. I've even seen recruiters try to get these policies changed, because we want to do right by the candidates and know it's upsetting not to receive specifics about your interview.

The thing is, recruiters are on your side - we want you to succeed. We want you to get the job. If you don't get the job, we want you to find success elsewhere. But often, respecting and representing company policy means we aren't able to share details about why decisions were made. It isn't personal, and it isn't because we want to keep information from you. We're doing the best we can and we know you are, too. ✨

We're all tired of hearing about how these are "unprecedented times" -- but it remains true. It occurred to me the other day that folks are going to start including accomplishments in the context of 𝘢 𝘨𝘭𝘰𝘣𝘢𝘭 𝘱𝘢𝘯𝘥𝘦𝘮𝘪𝘤 on their resume. 

Almost overnight, 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘺𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 changed. A lot of us went home from work one day and just... didn't go back. But the work didn't stop. 

Sure, some work didn't change much. Recruiting can be done from anywhere, so doing it remotely isn't a big accomplishment. But what about building and running a newly-remote team? Leading a huge migration and keeping everyone on track when you can't be in the same place? Planning a huge training that had to pivot overnight to virtual? 

Pay attention to what you're accomplishing or how you're innovating during these difficult times. There's bound to be some good stuff. ✔️
If you have a passion for beautiful web and mobile products, and there’s fire in your belly for doing work that matters, we want to hear from you.

I saw something I LOVED on a LinkedIn profile today, and it has to do with sandwiches. 🥪

But first: if you've ever done any research into how to write an effective resume, you know it's imperative to include quantifiable accomplishments + metrics.

Easier said than done, right? Early in my career, I had the same struggle -- my roles were administrative, direction-taking roles. I wasn't building or selling or achieving anything in particular. How was I supposed to show any metrics?

Enter sandwiches. What I saw today was the *perfect* example of how to quantify your abilities, even in a job that doesn't easily lend itself to doing so.

This person worked for a sandwich restaurant. It would be easy to use bullet points like, "Made sandwiches" and "Worked as part of a team." Instead, they said, "Created over 360 sandwiches daily at one of the fastest locations in the nation," and "Coordinated with groups of 3-6 [team members to build sandwiches]." 

It's a huge difference! Showing the numbers + the details helps set you apart. I'd certainly love to hire someone with the hustle to make 360 sandwiches a day, + the collaborative spirit to partner with 6 people to do so!

If you want to reach out to recruiters on LinkedIn, do it with a purpose. 

💥 Pay attention to what the recruiter works on; if their profile says they focus on technical roles, don't message them asking to learn more about the marketing department. 

💥 Make sure you're advocating for yourself. I get countless messages saying, essentially, "Here's my resume, can you find me a job?" That puts all the effort in the recruiter's hands, AND it doesn't get you closer to what YOU actually want. A better idea is to find the specific job(s) you're interested in, apply online, and THEN reach out to sell yourself if you feel so inclined. I want to assist- help me help you!

💥 Keep in mind that networking isn't just for when you're job hunting. Building relationships with folks will go a lot further if it is more than just, "I want XYZ job." 

LinkedIn is a great tool to enable networking and job hunting, but using it effectively and efficiently is key - for both recruiters AND job hunters. 

 #linkedintips #recruiting #jobhunting

I understand why recruiters get a bad rap.

While furloughed, I applied to jobs here & there (I believe in being prepared for any outcome & a furlough doesn't guarantee you'll be rehired, although thankfully I was). In almost every case, I experienced some form of ghosting. 

Sometimes it was no response at all, not even to reject my application. Other times it was radio silence after a conversation. Sometimes I requested post-rejection feedback only to have my message ignored. I knew they may not be allowed to share anything, but a response saying as such would have been helpful. 

I'm a recruiter. I get it - life gets so busy sometimes that it can be dang near impossible to send personalized responses to everyone. But you know what isn't hard? Mass email updates from The ATS™. Email templates for questions you're frequently asked. 𝑱𝒖𝒔𝒕 𝒈𝒆𝒕𝒕𝒊𝒏𝒈 𝒃𝒂𝒄𝒌 𝒕𝒐 𝒑𝒆𝒐𝒑𝒍𝒆. 

It requires give & take on both sides. For a job seeker, it requires acceptance that they likely won't get personal responses to everything, especially if the job isn't a fit. But as recruiters, we need to do better. Job hunting is stressful and just giving people an update or a response (even if it's "no") makes a difference. 

It's just the right thing to do.

Folks in the recruiting and career coaching world love to talk about the ATS and its ability to screen out candidates. So I ask you, recruiters of LinkedIn (and feel free to expand on this in the comments):

My new favorite thing is Lunchclub. When you join, you receive a weekly networking match based on your preferences, interests, and experience. (And it's a reminder of how small the world is! My first match lives practically in my neighborhood and the other works for a former boss of mine.)

It's currently invitation-only, but if you're interested, I have a few invitations I can send out.

I came across an article today detailing questions NOT to ask during your interview.

Some I agree with, others not as much. I definitely don't want to be asked, "Do you have any reservations about my candidacy?" or "Is anything missing from my background?" I rarely see those questions advance the conversation - I either don't have an answer yet, don't have reservations to share, or don't have reservations I'm *comfortable* sharing. I do, however, think it's fine to ask, "Is there any other information I can share?" although definitely not necessary.

The article said NOT to ask about flexible hours, why the role is open, or turnover. I disagree! It matters HOW you ask, but interviewing is a two-way street. I don't advise asking, "Can I have XYZ schedule?" prior to an offer, but it's fine to ask the typical schedules people work. Asking what led to the opening of the role can get you helpful context - was someone promoted (evidence of a growth culture) or did they leave? While you don't want to seem combative demanding turnover stats, asking how long folks stay in the role/stay with the company is reasonable and worth asking. Having, years ago, worked somewhere that had *extremely* high turnover, it's something I really wish I'd researched ahead of time! 

Link in comments. ⬇️

Things you ❌ DON'T ❌ need to include on your resume:

🚫 Your pay. It's your own business what you've been paid.
🚫 How many hours you worked at each job. Trust me, it doesn't matter if you worked 40 hours or 37.5 (and yes, I do see people include this!).
🚫 Your supervisor's name or contact info.
🚫 A list of references - or the phrase "references available upon request." That's a given in this day + age. 

Your resume is prime real estate - don't waste it! 

#resume

Those of us who are out of work are probably intimately familiar with the challenge of applying for unemployment. At least in WA, that means staring at your screen, repeatedly refreshing the page, reaching an error message, & timing out… then doing it all again. This morning, I’ve spent an hour trying to get through & just received a “come back later” message. Cool.

The system is broken. None of us have filed for unemployment during a pandemic; these times present new and unexpected challenges. It’s easy to wonder, “what’s the point?” and feel like giving up. I’d be lying if I said I didn’t want to chuck my laptop out the window in frustration a few minutes ago. 

But I also want my money, so I’ll keep at it. Maybe this is a weird metaphor for the times. An exercise in not giving up, perhaps. It’s easy to throw your hands up & say “these are unprecedented times, nothing is normal!” & not bother trying. But eventually, the Employment Security Department’s website WILL work (um, I hope). Eventually, you WILL find another job, so long as you keep looking. Don’t use this as time to get complacent; spend this time beefing up your resume, networking, figuring out your next move. The system (& frankly, the world) might be broken right now -- but we don’t have to be!

I started working at Connecteam — a startup company in Tel Aviv.
Just six months ago, Connecteam counted only 10 employees...Guess how many is it today?
45 and this number grows fast, with a goal to hit 90 by the end of this year!

Connecteam is providing a SaaS product for a high-demand market with enormous potential. 
The product is standalone and serves over 120,000 users and over 5,000 customers in Israel and around the world.
The number of customers has been increasing 4 times every year, and we saw a huge spike in 2020.
Our ARR triples every year and has long passed the millions mark.

Very excited to announce our partnership with François Baldassari, Christopher Coleman, Tyler Hoffman and the rest of the terrific Memfault team as they build the reliability platform for connected devices. 

The need for observability in devices is no less acute than in software, and yet today firmware developers typically can choose to either a) build and maintain it yourself, or b) fly blind. Memfault is the first platform of its kind that gives developers the ability to monitor, diagnose, and remediate firmware across virtually any hardware configuration. As connected devices permeate every vertical - from consumer, to auto, to medical devices, to aerospace and everything in between - we think Memfault has the potential to build the "Datadog for IoT."

cc: Vidhan Bhatt Fred Kauber Aaron Shapiro Julie Herendeen Colleen Harig Heiko Behrens Stripes 

press coverage: https://lnkd.in/esNv2CrM 

further thoughts: https://lnkd.in/eXYFTjrg

To all Americans and Europeans living in their comfortable homes in their democratic countries and demonstrating for the Palestinians in Gaza. 
Yes, you.

The Palestinians in Gaza want to tell you something. 
It goes like this:

We don't need you to help us break free from Israel.
Israel left Gaza 18 years ago. Not a single Israeli here for almost two decades. 

We need to get rid of the #HamasisISIS terrorists.
They steal the funds of your donations and become billionaires, and with what is left, they buy terrorist weapons and build terrorist tunnels to hide in.

Nothing is going to us citizens and our children - no education, health, development, knowledge, or hope. We get nothing.

Instead of turning Gaza into Singapore, they turned it into Afghanistan. Into hell. They turned us, our children, the schools, the hospitals into their human shields.

And your demonstrations don't help us.

You are only interrupting because people may think they are a legitimate government. Then, Hamas leaders will receive more donations and more funding. To do more of the same. 
And you are guilty of it too.

So you have two options:
1. demonstrate against Hamas and chant #freegazafromhamas, and fight for us - the citizens who want to live our lives and raise our families
2. shut up and let Israel do the hard and dangerous work for us and for you and eliminate the evil of Hamas from the face of earth.

And remember - we, those citizens of Gaza who are not terrorists, also #standwithisrael

איפה אתה רואה את עצמך בעוד עשר שנים? 🔮
זו השאלה שהייתי צריך לענות עליה בראיון.
חשבתי שהתשובה צריכה להיות בנאלית ומספקת -
״אני רוצה לנהל עסק חברתי״
״אני שואף להיות נציג ישראל בגוף בינלאומי״
״אני רוצה להיות דיפלומט באירופה״

מניח שאחת התשובות הייתה לא רק בנאלית אלא גם מספקת כי בסופו של דבר התקבלתי,
וכל מה שקרה אחרי זה שינה לחלוטין את החשיבה שלי.
כי המטרה אמנם הייתה להיות בחטיבת דאטה, ממשל ודמוקרטיה, אבל הדברים בדרך הם אלו שהשפיעו על כל המכלול.
זה לא רק לרצות להיות בוגר תכנית כזו או אחרת, זה לקחת כל הזדמנות שנקרית בדרך ולהפיק ממנה ערך.
זה לא רק להיות בתכנית מסוימת, זה ללמוד מ-0 דברים בלי שום אוריינטציה אליהם וליהנות מזה.
זה להיות עם 0 ניסיון ובכל זאת לקחת פרויקט ולהיכנס ב-200 קמ״ש כדי להצליח.
זה להתנסות, להרחיב את סט הכלים - המקצועיים, התיאורטיים, הבינאישיים - כדי שבעוד עשר שנים אני אהיה עם כל מה שצברתי עד היום - פלוס.
וזו המהות של כל מה שאנחנו עושים - לא רק להציב יעד, אלא לבנות או למקם או להיעזר באנשים כדי ליצור את אבני הדרך שיקחו אותנו לשם.

כשאנשים שואלים איפה אתה רואה את עצמך עוד כמה שנים, הם מתכוונים למטרה.
ואולי, אנחנו צריכים לחשוב לא רק על המטרה אלא על מה נשיג בדרך.
היום, כשישאלו אותי איפה אני אהיה בעתיד, אדע להגיד אילו דברים אני רוצה להשיג, ויהיה לי הכי ברור איך עושים את זה.

תודה לחטיבת הדאטה, תודה לדינגים, תודה לפרופ׳ נהון, תודה למרצים, תודה לאוניברסיטה - על הקרקע היציבה להניח עליה את אבני הדרך שלי בדרך ליעד 👾

“The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing” - Socrates

🏛
For the past few weeks I’ve been taking part in Reichman University (IDC Herzliya) collaboration program with National Security Studies Program at the Maxwell School, Syracuse University, initiated by the Gerald and Daphna Cramer foundation.

🇺🇸
During this time I had the opportunity to travel Syracuse, Washington DC, and NYC, have a glimpse at the USA, be exposed to its culture, people, politics, domestic and international matters.

🫱🏽‍🫲🏼
I had the chance of meeting the best professors in various research and practice fields, alongside meeting public figures, legislators and policy makers, agents and entrepreneurs.

🔮
I’m partly glad to realise how limited my knowledge had been, somewhat concerned about current common issues, and thrilled to understand how educative and practical this experience has been for what’s coming up next.

Oh and of course we had fun along the way 🤩

Grateful to conclude a national security class with the legendary Prof. Richard Shultz from The Fletcher School at Tufts University ! Thanks for this great opportunity!

Reichman University (IDC Herzliya) 
Orad Nave

I can't believe it's been a year working as an #intern at Abba Eban Institute For International Diplomacy, Reichman University.
It's hard to summarize everything but here are my key takeaways from this experience:
 
1. Some places can offer you everything, some are simply waiting for you to ask for it. Being eager to learn and work in fields I wouldn't initially try, really opened up my boundaries and my interests.

2. Hard work pays off. I was honored to have my take on defining Innovative Diplomacy in research, and to see the impact of our think tanks' market research.

3. Speaking of pay, sometimes it's not money that you receive back. Besides the useful tools from this internship, I was lucky to be with an amazing team, and learn a lot about diplomacy-oriented matters but also about myself.
 

I'm happy to say that I got back a lot more than I gave and that this year has developed me and helped shape the way I see myself today and in the future.
 
Geroge P. Shultz, former US secretary of state, said " You've got to dream a little bit if you're going to get somewhere" - So dream! And make sure you enjoy it 😇

George Zimmer is the well-known founder of Men's Warehouse. After 35+ years as the CEO, Zimmer was fired by the board of directors in 2013 for not being "hip enough." 

Instead of retiring, Zimmer founded Generation Tux, a startup that's changing the way men rent tuxes and suits through its one-of-a-kind 'high tech high touch' online platform. 

Zimmer is speaking at Hustle Con 2016 (http://hustlecon.com/) on how to successfully build an iconic brand, even when you're up against a well-known company in the industry.

I joined Wix almost a decade ago, a young , small company with an inspiring vision to allow anyone to create anything online . I was trying to make a change and get out of the data industry, so I joined wix and no surprises- I found myself starting the data team at Wix . 
Since then I was a living example of internal growth.
 From leading the marketing operations, chief of staff to our CEO and starting Wix’s business operations team ( when the profession did not exist in Israel) to leading wix global exapansion. Every position I took was different , however, in all of them I tried to explain ( to myself and others) the reasoning behind the super fast, sometimes chaotic, appearance of events . It took some years for me to understand that what makes things tick , is more than processes , tools or org structure- it’s the people ! It’s all of you I walked (ran) this journey with , and it takes to be a wixer to really get it. 
I have worked with the top talent in the industry- smart , hard workers , caring and full with spirit , it is you who made and still do make the wonder at wix. 
So , to all of you I want to thank - thank you for making me the person, manager and professional I am today . I had lots of fun while doing that :)!
Now, a decade later , I am moving on to a place I can implement everything I have learned and grow in a different industry as the next step in my career.
I am very excited to join the smart , enthusiastic, growing team of Pagaya as COO in Israel. 
I can’t wait to see what the future holds for us and I'm very happy to experience it as Pagayan. 

Love you all ,love wix, please stay in touch - I am always a phone call away.

Eyal

#Wix #Pagaya

Learn how Harmony IoT Wireless Digital Security can assist in protecting industrial companies utilizing Industry 4 0

Flexible, flawless, large scale machine-to-machine (M2M) communication is critical for Industry 4.0 and smart factories to succeed and is driving the adoption of wireless communication technologies like Zigbee, Bluetooth, LoRa, and Wi-Fi. The dark side of these technologies is that they open up factories to a new world of cyber airspace risk. Cyber attack techniques that used to be only in the realm of IT have now jumped the fence to OT, and are being used not just to steal data, but also to disrupt manufacturing processes. Wireless attacks like Karma, Evil Twin, or Wireless Deauth can be highly effective in disrupting manufacturing processes and even short disruptions can cost tens of thousands of euros. Find out how to protect your wireless production before you are attacked. #cybersecurity #security #iot  #manufacturing40 #manufacturing

When there's a vacancy on your church staff, the search process can feel daunting and overwhelming.

It's hard enough to get everyone on the same page and craft an effective job description. Then, as the pastor search committee, you’re tasked with discerning how to evaluate candidates for the role. 

Our team here at @Vanderbloemen is passionate about helping churches understand that a candidate is much more than a resume. You can't fully capture a person on one sheet of paper. A resume should be one tool of many that helps you evaluate whether or not a candidate is the right fit for the role.

Some job searchers are adept at creating impressive resumes, even with little real or pertinent experience. 

Others may possess the skills and experience needed, but you may have to dig a little past the resume to find that out. While a resume is (or should be!) a good summary of a person’s work experience and accomplishments, it is important to remember that it is just a snapshot, and sometimes that can be misleading.

Here are seven things your search committee should look for when evaluating resumes. 
#Staffing #MinistryResume #PastorSearch

Don't give up, how I found a job after returning home from abroad.

I wanted to share my story about finding a job after a long journey abroad. For the past few years, I've been living and working in Florida, experiencing new cultures, learning new things, and making unforgettable memories. It's been an incredible journey, but it also meant that I was away from my home country and the job market for a while.

When I decided to return home, I knew that finding a job wouldn't be easy. My resume had gaps, my network was mostly overseas, and I was out of the loop on the latest industry trends and job openings. But I was determined to make it work.
I started by updating my LinkedIn profile and making sure it reflected my international experience and skills. I also reached out to my network, both abroad and at home, to see if they had any leads or could make introductions for me. I also spent a lot of time researching companies and industries that I was interested in, and tailoring my job applications to fit those specific roles.
It wasn't easy, and there were definitely moments of doubt and frustration. But I kept at it, and eventually I landed a job that I'm truly excited about.

If you're in a similar situation, I encourage you to stay positive and keep trying. It may take some time and effort, but it's possible to find a job that aligns with your passions and goals, even after a long journey abroad.

הכירו את Mabrooc Project (R.A), אשר שם לו למטרה לקדם את הערבות והסולידריות החברתית בישראל, ומאפשר לזוגות שידם אינה משגת לקיים חתונה ראויה ומכובדת.
בשנים האחרונות, הפרויקט התפתח באופן מרשים וחיתן כבר 57 זוגות בחתונה "מברוקית". כל זה קורה באמצעות גיבוש קהילת מתנדבים והתנעת שיתופי פעולה עם משרדים ממשלתיים, גופים פרטיים וציבוריים וספקים מעולם האירועים שפתחו את הלב ובחרו להפוך חלומות למציאות.

כבר 5 שנים שאני מתנדבת בעמותה. שמעתי על הפרויקט לראשונה, כסטודנטית בעברית, ויחד עם חבורת אנשים מופלאה הקמתי את הצוות הירושלמי. בשנים האחרונות אני מנהלת את השיווק ויחסי הציבור של העמותה וזוכה לראות מקרוב כיצד מברוק הפך ל-"תרופת הפלא" המאחדת ומחברת בין א.נשים מכל קשת החברה הישראלית במטרה אחת: לעשות טוב.

למה לינקדין? כי אנחנו מגייסים את הצוותים לשנת הפעילות 2022-2023!

אם הלב שלכם נמצא במקום הנכון ואתם יודעים לזוז היטב על הרחבה -מקומכם איתנו.
מזמינה אתכם.ן לעשות מעבר ולהצטרף לחבורת האנשים שהופכים הכל לאפשרי ומכוונים תמיד לחלל.

תעופו על ההזדמנות ותרשמו לראיונות: https://bit.ly/3HsdH5j
להצצה לאתר ולסיפור שלנו: https://lnkd.in/dC2qKtUr
